text: hi everyone first thingy dos tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
serpent with
feet project deacon this is the
sophomore lp
of art pop and alternative r b artist
josiah wise aka serpent with feet
one of my most anticipated albums of the
year given just how much promise was
shown
on josiah's debut soil along with some
of the heartwarming sentiments expressed
on teasers like same-sized shoe and
fellowship i thought deacon might not
only shape up to
be a better album than soil but maybe a
much
needed ray of light and hope after
an incredibly dark year but if you
remember as much as i did enjoy
soil i did have my reservations with it
mostly with the instrumentals not being
detailed or
layered enough to adequately support
josiah's very beautiful and unique voice
but on deacon that issue doesn't seem to
have
resolved on some tracks i actually think
it's gotten worse
yes at least on several tracks here
there seems to be even
less going on instrumentally and look in
concept i'm not against the idea of
taking a minimal approach certainly
there are other artists
in the fields of artpop and r b that
have shown you can do
a lot with a little be that twigs or
sebdeliza or moses sumnee
perfume genius but for me deacon reads
as more awkward
and unfinished than it does minimal take
the track malik for example
lyrically it does seem like a lot of
thought and a lot of heart went into
this one
but then consider the bland and stiff
kick
clap patterns the plain pianos the basic
reverbs the sudden ending
sonically the track is about as
uninspired as it gets
the track amir is similarly flat and dry
as is it sounds like the frame of a
house
just like the walls and the finishings
haven't really been put up yet
the mix on the track wood boy is
especially rough too
with its dusty chugging beats enveloping
dungeon synths
and thick reverb vocal harmonies all of
which
clash as they overlap and while the
vocals on this lp are easily the most
standout characteristic
about it they don't come off nearly as
ambitious bold or as
eccentric as they did on soil now look
overall i did find this record
underwhelming but
still listenable and there were some
relative highlights that made that the
case
maybe not tracks that i thought were
much better than anything on soil but
maybe just as good we have the
intriguing intro track which is like a
dronier dreamier take on a frank ocean
ballad
it's bright it's hopeful it's gorgeous
there's also the track sailor
superstition which is one of the few
moments on the record where
the beats and grooves actually go over
quite smoothly they don't feel
too naked or too stiff the glossy keys
and pads that sneak in on the chorus
are a great touch i think josiah also
really nails it on the background vocals
plus narratively the track ties in
really well with the record's overall
themes of love but this time with a
paranoid twist
there's also an element of queerness
that plays into that the idea of
receiving judgment for being open about
this
love he's singing of but as you read
into the lyrics there's also this vague
sense of
bringing on bad energy by solidifying
the
relationship more or getting complacent
in it in some way
hence the superstition in the title i
also love the refrain
don't whistle on the ship meaning you
know don't uh act like things are great
or chill or
smooth sailing on this ship or else uh
some bad stuff might come
yield jinx how great things are i mean i
think this track lyrically and
conceptually is just good writing all
around
another highlight for me on the record
was heart storm featuring now
who i think has a great vocal dynamic
with josiah on the track
the heavy rushes of bass and keys at a
few points of the song make for some of
the most
dynamic musical passages on the entire
lp2
and the closing fellowship i found
instrumentally and also emotionally to
be one of the lovelier spots on the lp i
love the organic layers of
vocals and percussion throughout while
structurally this may be one of the more
singular songs on the lp
i think the the track isn't really about
that it's more about this sense of
togetherness and
and oneness with people that you care
about people you love created musically
through what sounds like
an intimate jam session between a bunch
of musicians but again as much as i can
commend these tracks they don't make up
the majority of the record which by the
way is pretty scant as well
uh the couple of interlude tracks here
just barely
pad this thing out to 29 minutes i found
this record to be conceptually inspiring
with its nods to love
and emotional intimacy but musically
underwhelming with some of the most
bland and uninspired instrumentals i've
heard on any of serpent with feed stuff
to date feeling a strong five to a light
six on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry
hit the bell as well over here next to
my head is another video that you can
check out
hit that up worthy link to subscribe to
the channel anthony fantano
serpent with feet forever
